statement:
JSON is included in 2 national catalogues of recommended specifications. They belong to the Netherlands and Slovenia. The National Interoperability Framework (NIF) of these Member States is fully aligned with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the European Interoperability Framework (EIF) according to the National Interoperability Framework Observatory (NIFO) factsheets.
See:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/national-interoperability-framework-observatory-nifo/nifo-factsheets

JSON strongly supports Tim Berners Lee's 5-star schema for open data. The adoption of JSON fosters the publication of data as open data by means of providing structured data and the usage of non-proprietary formats. Moreover, it helps to link data by means of embedding metadata. 

See: 
https://www.europeandataportal.eu/sites/default/files/european_data_portal_-_open_data_goldbook.pdf
https://5stardata.info/en/

ECMA International has clearly defined the procedures that have to be carried out in order to publish standards or technical reports. The procedures are defined in a set of documents that can be found at ECMA's webpage. 

ECMA Internationalâ€™s decision procedure is basically a two-step process: The first decision step takes place on the level of the Technical Committee (TC) level where consensus is the primary target.  The second step is approval at the ECMA International General Assembly.

See:
http://www.ecma-international.org/memento/policies.htm

The Executive Committee has to review and co-ordinate the progress of the TCs and, from time to time, review the terms of reference given to Technical Committees. 

In addition, the Technical Committee shall review and approve the minutes of the preceding meeting. The minutes, after approval, shall constitute the official record of the meeting of a TC

See:
http://www.ecma-international.org/memento/policies.htm

JSON is available for its use, study and implementation at ECMA International and EITF's webpages. 
See:
https://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-404.htm
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259

ECMA International's purpose is to make available the developed standards and specifications in a non-discriminatory and free of charges. Therefore, JSON is licensed under (F)RAND and Royalty-free basis. Terms and conditions for IPR disclosures can be found in ECMA's webpage. 
See:
http://www.ecma-international.org/memento/Ecma%20IPR%20policies.htm

ECMA International's purpose is to make available the developed standards and specifications in a non-discriminatory and free of charges. Therefore, JSON is licensed under (F)RAND and Royalty-free basis. Terms and conditions for IPR disclosures can be found in ECMA's webpage. 
See:
http://www.ecma-international.org/memento/Ecma%20IPR%20policies.htm

Douglas Crockford was the creator of JSON. The system was sold to Sun Microsystems, Amazon.com and EDS. The website of the specification was launched in 2002. JSON reuses conventions from other programming languages, in consequence, many libraries of programming use it. Therefore, it is demonstrated that JSON has enough maturity and market acceptance for its use in the development of products and services. 

See:
https://www.json.org/json-en.html

Currently, JSON is a widely used specification for data interchange between applications and platforms. It is used in a REST API applications in order to ensure data exchange, this application is extensively used for the creation of solutions, including innovative ones.

JSON is available for its use an implementation at ECMA International and EITF's webpages. 
See:
https://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-404.htm
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259

JSON is a specification used for data exchange between different platforms, this fact facilitates the visibility and comprehensibility of administration's data. Moreover, it eases the communication between administrations enhancing the decision-making process.
The purpose of JSON is not related to ensuring the availability of interfaces. Therefore this criterion is not applicable to this specification.
JSON sector agnostic specification that can be reused in any business domain requiring a common format to exchange data between different programs.

JSON is available for its use an implementation at ECMA International and EITF's webpages. 
See:
https://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-404.htm
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8259#section-14.1

JSON is a text format that is completely language independent.  The specification uses conventions that are familiars to C-family of languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, JavaScript, Perl, Python, and many others. For these reasons, JSON is an optimum data exchange and interchange language.

JSON is a lightweight specification that allows data exchange between different applications fostering interoperability and data visibility. The specification is scarcely used for document exchange. Therefore, JSON adoption does not hamper the interoperability and scalability of systems. 

See:
https://www.json.org/xml.html
By allowing the data exchange between applications and systems talking different languages JSON fosters the data portability of European public services.

As a key enabler for the data exchange and interchange between administrations and stakeholders, JSON enhances the communication and information exchange across borders between public administrations. Therefore, the adoption of the specification avoids citizens and businesses to provide information in several times.
The purpose of JSON is not related to e-accessibility. Therefore this criterion is not applicable to this specification.

JSON in itself does not provide security features, which is a weakness per se. The storage of private date as JSON format is not recommended in order to avoid malicious activities against stored information. Despite this, there are several additional features with the aim of protecting data exchange.

JSON is a data-interchange format is used by APIs, which are involved in the delivery of information between platforms, and in consequence service delivery. This fact makes JSON an element that fosters de delivery of European Public services, including multilingual ones.

JSON allows the data exchange and consumption from different administrations stakeholders. Ensuring data exchange through applications avoids the interaction by means of reducing the non-digital data exchange. Therefore, the adoption of JSON eases the reduction of administrative burden.
The purpose of JSON is not related to long-term preservation of electronic records. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable to this specification.

There are already existing documents and studies assessing the JSON's features and performance. In some cases, the study has been carried out in a comprehensive comparison between XML and JSON. 
See: 
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hanif_Ullah/publication/321361853_Behavior_based_Comparative_analysis_of_XML_and_JSON_web_technologies/links/5a1eb56f0f7e9b9d5e000bfd/Behavior-based-Comparative-analysis-of-XML-and-JSON-web-technologies.pdf 
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kamir_Yusof/publication/320045078_Efficiency_of_JSON_for_data_retrieval_in_big_data/links/5a3f14ea458515f6b0456f54/Efficiency-of-JSON-for-data-retrieval-in-big-data.pdf

JSON is already associated with EIRA ABBs in the European Library Of Specifications (ELIS). Specifically, JSON can define the interoperability aspects of the "Machine to machine interface" ABB of the EIRA Technical View. In addition, JSON can define also the "representation" ABB of the EIRA semantic view. 
See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/elis/distribution/eliscataloguev100betaxlsx

There are several existing mechanisms to assess JSON conformity. Different types of validators depending on usersâ€™ needs.
See: 
https://github.com/nst/JSONTestSuite
https://jsoncompare.com/#!/simple/
https://jsonformatter.curiousconcept.com/

5 Member States are recommending JSON in their ICT National Catalogues. 
See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

The specification has been selected as one of the key elements for the data interchange between administrations and stakeholders. 

Europeana is using JSON within the Search API, the method created to diving into the european cross-border project data. These features allow retrieving information from EUROPEANA. 

Moreover, the Single Electronic Data Interchange Area (SEDIA) is using JSON as the basis to make data available for stakeholders. Examples SEDIA activity is the Call for Tenders, a key point on European eProcurement. Additionally, the EU Open Data Portal is another cross-border initiative that relies on JSON as a message format for APIâ€™s communication. 

See: 
https://pro.europeana.eu/resources/apis/search
https://ec.europa.eu/info/funding-tenders/opportunities/portal/screen/support/apis
http://data.europa.eu/euodp/en/data/dataset/eu-open-data-portal-api

The specification is included in 5 Member States' catalogues of recommended specifications. Some examples of Member States including JSON on their catalogues are the Netherlands, Spain or Belgium.
See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards
Nowadays, JSON is not included in any supra-national catalogue of standards.
No formal interoperability agreement has been found involving European public services providers.

After checking the assessments performed by CAMSS and the list of specifications identified by the MSP Multi-stakeholder-platform, no assessment verifying the compliance of the specification with the European standardisation regulation has been found.
The purpose of JSON is not related  to the modelling of business processes. Therefore, this criterion is not applicable to the specification.
The purpose of JSON is not related to organisational interoperability. Therefore, this criterion is not applicable to the specification.

JSON is defining a set of rules to format data in order to ensure the proper data exchange between applications and platforms. Even defining rules, it can not be considered as a data model in itself, therefore, JSON is not defining a cross-sector data model.

JSON highly supports Tim Berners Lee's 5 star schema for open data. The adoption of JSON fosters the publication of data as open data by means of providing structured data and the usage of non-proprietary formats. Moreover, it helps to link data by means of embedding metadata. 

Moreover, there is an existing extension of JSON which aims to help and support the Linked Open Data environments. The extension has been developed by the W3C working group specifically in charge of JSON-LD development. Additionally, the W3C has developed a syntax for RDF serialisation using JSON, and JSON-LD is recommended. 

See:
https://www.w3.org/community/json-ld/
https://json-ld.org

JSON is available for free at the European Collaborative Platform Joinup. 
See:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/json-rfc7159-javascript-object-notation-json/distribution/json-rfc7159-javascript-object-notation-json
